channel.title: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: California's Strawberry Feud Ends, But Who Will Breed New Berries?
item.description: Strawberry farmers have dropped a lawsuit against the University of California, Davis, and the university has hired a new strawberry breeder. But the future of academic berry breeding is uncertain.
item.content:encoded:
Strawberry farmers have dropped a lawsuit against the University of California, Davis, and the university has hired a new strawberry breeder. But the future of academic berry breeding is uncertain.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dan Charles

item.title: Scientific Pros Weigh The Cons Of Messing With Earth's Thermostat
item.description: Studying techniques for engineering our way out of climate change would be helpful — and not the same as actually trying them, says a panel convened by the National Research Council.
item.content:encoded:
Studying techniques for engineering our way out of climate change would be helpful — and not the same as actually trying them, says a panel convened by the National Research Council.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: The Great Solar Panel Debate: To Lease Or To Buy?
item.description: More homeowners are cutting energy costs by installing solar panels, due in part to leasing programs that require no up-front investment. Leasing means less hassle, but may also save you less money.
item.content:encoded:
More homeowners are cutting energy costs by installing solar panels, due in part to leasing programs that require no up-front investment. Leasing means less hassle, but may also save you less money.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Jeff Brady

item.title: Shake, Rattle And Toll: Berkeley's Bells Play Sounds Of Earth
item.description: In celebration of its 100th anniversary, the bells of UC Berkeley's Sather Tower were programmed to play a score composed in real time by the data from seismic shifts happening under the campus.
item.content:encoded:
In celebration of its 100th anniversary, the bells of UC Berkeley's Sather Tower were programmed to play a score composed in real time by the data from seismic shifts happening under the campus.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Laura Sydell

item.title: In West Africa, Fewer New Ebola Cases But Epidemic Still Uncontained
item.description: Robert Siegel speaks with Brice de le Vingne, director of operations dealing with the Ebola outbreak for Doctors without Borders.
item.content:encoded:
Robert Siegel speaks with Brice de le Vingne, director of operations dealing with the Ebola outbreak for Doctors without Borders.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Harnessing The Immune System To Fight Cancer
item.description: Our immune systems constantly fight off disease — protecting us from colds, flu and infection. An experimental treatment called immunotherapy is helping patients' immune systems fight off cancer.
item.content:encoded:
Our immune systems constantly fight off disease — protecting us from colds, flu and infection. An experimental treatment called immunotherapy is helping patients' immune systems fight off cancer.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: 16 Years After Its Inception, 'GoreSat' Set For Launch ... Soon
item.description: In 1998, then-Vice President Gore proposed the satellite, which has since been repurposed for NOAA's needs. It was set to take off Sunday, but the launch was scrubbed, and will be rescheduled.
item.content:encoded:
In 1998, then-Vice President Gore proposed the satellite, which has since been repurposed for NOAA's needs. It was set to take off Sunday, but the launch was scrubbed, and will be rescheduled.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Medical Research And The End Of Privacy
item.description: Scientists can no longer guarantee privacy for patients donating tissue and DNA for medical research. NPR's Arun Rath talks with Jennifer Couzin-Frankel of Science Magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists can no longer guarantee privacy for patients donating tissue and DNA for medical research. NPR's Arun Rath talks with Jennifer Couzin-Frankel of Science Magazine.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Birders Predict Another Snowy Owl 'Irruption'
item.description: In 2014, ornithologists documented record numbers of snowy owls wintering unusually far south. NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Talkin' Birds host Ray Brown about this year's numbers.
item.content:encoded:
In 2014, ornithologists documented record numbers of snowy owls wintering unusually far south. NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Talkin' Birds host Ray Brown about this year's numbers.

» E-Mail This

item.title: To Get Parents To Vaccinate Their Kids, Don't Ask. Just Tell
item.description: The way a pediatrician talks with nervous parents about vaccines may determine whether the child gets immunized or not, a study suggests. Asking "What do you want to do about shots?" doesn't work.
item.content:encoded:
The way a pediatrician talks with nervous parents about vaccines may determine whether the child gets immunized or not, a study suggests. Asking "What do you want to do about shots?" doesn't work.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Patti Neighmond

item.title: Satellite Set To Stream Daily Images Of Earth From Space
item.description: In 1998, Al Gore proposed using a satellite and the Internet to let us all see the awe-inspiring view of Earth that wows space travelers. That satellite may finally launch later this year.
item.content:encoded:
In 1998, Al Gore proposed using a satellite and the Internet to let us all see the awe-inspiring view of Earth that wows space travelers. That satellite may finally launch later this year.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Joe Palca

item.title: Being With People Like You Offers Comfort Against Death's Chill
item.description: Iggy Ignatius bet that immigrants from India would long to live with other Indians in his Florida condos. He was right. Psychologists say intimations of mortality make us want to be with our own kind.
item.content:encoded:
Iggy Ignatius bet that immigrants from India would long to live with other Indians in his Florida condos. He was right. Psychologists say intimations of mortality make us want to be with our own kind.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Lulu Miller

item.title: What Microbes Lurk In The Subways Of New York? Mysteries Abound
item.description: Think expedition to the rain forest, but one where you'll need a MetroCard to get around. The microbial life of the New York subways turns out to be as rich, odd and confounding as the city itself.
item.content:encoded:
Think expedition to the rain forest, but one where you'll need a MetroCard to get around. The microbial life of the New York subways turns out to be as rich, odd and confounding as the city itself.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Nancy Shute

item.title: Outrage Over Government's Animal Experiments Leads To USDA Review
item.description: Lawmakers also introduced a bill to strengthen laws protecting farm animals used in research. Both moves come out of a New York Times investigation of animal suffering at a federal research center.
item.content:encoded:
Lawmakers also introduced a bill to strengthen laws protecting farm animals used in research. Both moves come out of a New York Times investigation of animal suffering at a federal research center.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: What Did Cavemen Think About Lust?
item.description: Christopher Ryan says that human beings are sexual omnivores and hopes that a better understanding of sexual fidelity may end discrimination, shame and unrealistic expectations.
item.content:encoded:
Christopher Ryan says that human beings are sexual omnivores and hopes that a better understanding of sexual fidelity may end discrimination, shame and unrealistic expectations.
